offer.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to ask someone if they would like to have something, or to hold something out to them so that they can take it
offer.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Can I offer you something to drink?
They offered him a very good job, but he turned it down.
Maureen lit a cigarette and offered one to Lucy.
The drama school offers places to students who can show talent.
offer.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to say that you are willing to do something
offer.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: I don’t need any help, but it was nice of you to offer.
My dad has offered to pick us up.
The newspaper offered to apologise for the article.
offer.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to provide something that people need or want
offer.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: A number of groups offer their services free of charge.
The Centre offers a wide range of sports facilities.
Your doctor should be able to offer advice on diet.
The course offers the opportunity to specialize in the final year.
I did what I could to offer comfort to the family.
offer.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to say that you are willing to pay a particular amount of money for something
offer.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: They’ve offered us £75,000 for the house.
The police are offering a reward for any information.
offer.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a statement saying that you are willing to do something for someone or give them something
offer.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: I can’t turn down the offer of a free trip to Milan!
His offer to resign will be accepted.
offer.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: an amount of money that you are willing to pay for something
offer.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Within 20 minutes they were prepared to make us an offer.
The company made an offer of $5 million for the site.
‘I’ll be interested if Newcastle make me a good offer, ’ said the 25-year-old striker.
We’re asking £2,500, but we’re open to offers.
offer.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a reduction of the price of something in a shop for a short time
offer.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: All special offers advertised in this brochure are subject to availability.
To take advantage of this offer (=buy something at the reduced price), complete the attached forms.
There’s a free offer on orders over £45.
offer.translation[1].note_box[0].section: accept an offer
Are you going to accept their offer?
take up an offer/take somebody up on their offer
I might take him up on his offer.
turn down/refuse/reject/decline an offer
She declined the offer of a lift.
get/receive an offer
He received the offer of a place at Cambridge University.
withdraw an offer
They suddenly withdrew their offer at the last minute.
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + offer
a job offer
I still did not have a formal job offer.
a kind/generous offer
We are grateful for your kind offer.
They were surprised by his generous offer to let them stay at his place.
an offer of help/support/friendship etc
Any offers of help would be appreciated.
I appreciate your offer
I appreciate your offer, but I don’t need any help.
offer.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to say that you are willing to give someone something, or to give them it
offer.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: They offered him a very good job, but he turned it down.
The magazine offered discounts to advertisers.
offer.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to say that you are willing to pay a particular amount of money for something
offer.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: They’ve offered us $200,000 for the house.
offer.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: to make an investment available for sale
offer.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: The company offered about 18 million shares to investors on the Tokyo Stock Exchange at 6,800 yen each.
offer.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: to provide a product or service
offer.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: It offers six credit cards with varying rates.
offer.translation[2].definitions[4].defi: if a product or service offers particular advantages or features, it has those features or advantages
offer.translation[2].definitions[4].exam: Different software packages offer different features.
offer.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: a statement that you are willing to give someone something or do something for them
offer.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: They approached him with the new job offer and, within hours, he accepted the post.
Before the offers of early retirement, the company had about 8,000 employees.
Their offer to buy the building was accepted.
offer.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: an amount of money that you are willing to pay for something
offer.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The company made an offer of $5 million for the site.
The company declined (=refused) the $1-a-share offer because it wanted $3 a share.
offer.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: to be ready to consider different offers of money or other things people are willing to give you
offer.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: We have no definite plans to sell but we are certainly open to offers.
offer.translation[3].definitions[3].defi: available to be bought or used
offer.translation[3].definitions[3].exam: It’s still a seller’s market because of the shortage of property on offer.
offer.translation[3].definitions[4].defi: available for a short time at a reduced price
offer.translation[3].definitions[4].exam: Olive oil is on offer this week.
This wine is currently on special offer at £3.29.
offer.translation[3].definitions[5].defi: a reduction in the price of something for a short time
offer.translation[3].definitions[5].exam: Take advantage of our ‘buy six for the price of five’ offer.
The ferry company is running a special offer: a day trip to France for only £7.
offer.translation[3].definitions[6].defi: if property that is for sale is under offer, someone has offered an amount of money for it
offer.translation[3].definitions[6].exam: We can confirm the club is under offer, but that’s as much as we can say at this stage.
